title: Added support for 17 foreign languages & for custom dictionaries
body:
Added support for 17 foreign languages + it's now possible to pass a custom hunspell dictionary. List of default supported languages is returned with ```r supported_languages() [1] "english" "bulgarian" "croatian" "danish" "dutch" [6] "french" "german" "greek" "icelandic" "italian" [11] "norwegian" "polish" "portuguese_european" "russian" "slovenian" [16] "spanish" "swedish" "turkish" "custom" ``` tokenization is handled by modified functions from the {tokenizers} package (see utils.R and tokenizers_foreign.R) Foreign languages can be parsed as usual (ngrams, html, etc). Added a Vignette about foreign languages. Examples : ```r library(tidytext) library(dplyr) supported_languages() fr <- tibble::tibble(txt = c("C'est dans l'arrière-cuisine. On s'en sert pour ranger.", "On aime l'arrière-saison. On part toujours en vacances à ce moment")) fr %>% unnest_tokens(word, txt, lang = "french") # A tibble: 25 x 1 word 1 c 2 est 3 dans 4 l 5 arrière 6 cuisine 7 on 8 s 9 en 10 sert # ... with 15 more rows fr %>% unnest_tokens(ngram, txt, token = "ngrams", n = 2, lang = "french") # A tibble: 24 x 1 ngram 1 c est 2 est dans 3 dans l 4 l arrière 5 arrière cuisine 6 cuisine on 7 on s 8 s en 9 en sert 10 sert pour # ... with 14 more rows data_frame(row = 1:2, text = c("

Du text ici", "C'est l'ancien site")) %>% unnest_tokens(word, text, format = "html", lang = "french") # A tibble: 8 x 2 row word 1 1 du 2 1 text 3 1 ici 4 2 c 5 2 est 6 2 l 7 2 ancien 8 2 site tibble::tibble(txt = c("Mir geht’s nicht gut.", "Darf ich mit Kreditkarte bezahlen? ")) %>% unnest_tokens(word, txt, lang = "german") # A tibble: 10 x 1 word 1 mir 2 geht 3 s 4 nicht 5 gut 6 darf 7 ich 8 mit 9 kreditkarte 10 bezahlen # turkish tibble::tibble(txt = c("İyiyim teşekkür ederim, siz nasılsınız", "Türkçe konuşur musunuz?")) %>% unnest_tokens(word, txt, lang = "turkish") # A tibble: 8 x 1 word 1 i̇yiyim 2 teşekkür 3 ederim 4 siz 5 nasılsınız 6 türkçe 7 konuşur 8 musunuz #russian tibble::tibble(txt = c("Говорите, пожалуйста, медленнее. Вы говорите по-английски?", "К сожалению, мне (нам) пора идти.")) %>% unnest_tokens(word, txt, lang = "russian") # A tibble: 13 x 1 word 1 говорите 2 пожалуйста 3 медленнее 4 вы 5 говорите 6 по 7 английски 8 к 9 сожалению 10 мне 11 нам 12 пора 13 идти ``` With a custom dictionary ```r df_latin <- tibble(text = "Alea Jacta Est.") download.file("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/titoBouzout/Dictionaries/master/la.aff", "la.aff") unnest_tokens(df_latin, word, text, lang = "custom", dict = "la.aff") # A tibble: 3 x 1 word 1 alea 2 jacta 3 est ```

title: Ensure compatibility w/quanteda v1.0
body:
Makes `cast_dfm()` and `tidy.dfm[Sparse]()` compatible with quanteda v0.99.12 and with the upcoming **quanteda** v1.0 release, and fixes some tests.

In v1.0 (and in the current quanteda `master` >= v0.9.9000), the dfm structure has been simplified to just `dfm`, instead of `dfmSparse` and `dfmDense`. Methods to check and to coerce the object class exist as `is.dfm()` and `as.dfm()`.

title: Stopwords fr
body:
As said in PR #85, lexicon can't be put as raw data in the package, as it has non ascii characters which are turned into UTF8 when calling the function. 

This refers to issue #76 and #53

title: Sentiments fr
body:
Added the sentiment lexicon from FEEL — as disussed in #76 — from: http://www.lirmm.fr/~abdaoui/FEEL

The main reason why we can't put the fr sentiment in the same dataset as the current sentiment is that french lexicon contains non ascii characters which gives error when checking. The lexicons in {proustr} are created as integer and are turned to UTF8 when calling the functions (same goes for stopwords). 

Calling this function from {proustr} also allows {idytext} to be lighter than an a package including also these data. 

This being said, I wasn't sure how to handle the documentation of this lexicon. If you think of a good way, I'll write the doc.

title: stemming
body:
Here's a function for stemming a one-word-per-row data.frame, as suggested in #17.

Default function works for english, and can be piped from a df containing a `word` column. It can be extended to other languages supported by `SnowballC`. 

I chose to keep the doc at its bare minimum so you can complete it and keep it uniform.

title: tm uses the snowball lexicon, not onix
body: `?tm::stopwords` says that it supports the `snowball` list of stopwords (when `kind = 'en'`) and `SMART`.  The length of these vectors matches the grouped by lexicon row counts within `tidytext::stop_words` so I'm guessing the reference to `onix` here is just a typo.

title: Fix tests and #34
body:
This patch fixes a pair of bugs in the unit tests, respectively:

1. Where the topicmodels package was required, but part of both a quiet require() test *and* a library call...meaning that if the package wasn't loaded, it'd die on library() and the nice require check would be for naught.

2. Where the quanteda package and its underlying `dfmSparse` class were assumed loaded, which wasn't a guarantee or check that the test file performed.

In addition, it turns unnest_tokens into an S3 generic, as requested by #34 - I figure I'll build a data.table method in as the next patch.

repo.description: Text mining using dplyr, ggplot2, and other tidy tools :sparkles::page_facing_up::sparkles::page_facing_up::sparkles:
repo.name: tidytext

title: Issue 28
body:
This fixes #28, by replacing the direct calls to the internal objects of a **quanteda** corpus with the accessor functions from that package. This means that with the imminent redesign of a quanteda corpus object, to include indexing and tagging, `tidy.corpus` and `glance.corpus` will still work.

It does this at the cost of adding a **quanteda** import to `DESCRIPTION` but I am hoping that with all of the coming **quanteda** features that will enhance **tidytext** this will be viewed as worth it!
